segments.text: We got up near the Teutoburger Wall and there's a road running perpendicular to our advance and that happened to be the outer perimeter road of a Panzer training center, German tank training center, at which time we would come under heavy tank fire.

I deployed all the tanks units the infantry got itself married up with the tanks and the artillery began to take them under fire and we had quite a tank battle there my own personal tank knocked out one German tank at 1500 yards and another one that turned its gun out of some
small fir trees at 75 yards.
75 yards?
75 yards.
That's probably the closest one you ever shot at.
That's the closest I was ever in.
Closest one I ever shot at.
Did you shoot at him?
We shot at him.
I didn't even give a chance to give the gunner orders.
He just happened to be looking through the scope when he saw this barrel turn around and I pressed the mic button to tell him
and at that time the gun went off and killed that thing.
That was Sergeant Cooley.

The story about Sergeant Cooley, he had a brother that was in the maintenance part of the regiment and he was a cook and he became the head mess sergeant in my headquarters company and war was going pretty
pretty well we were in the pursuit and exploitation phase as we were at this particular time and he just had to get out of that kitchen he said.
These were mobile kitchens and he had been a good tank gunner as a corporal but we also you know you need a mess sergeant so he had been promoted up to mess sergeant.
He wanted to
go along as my tank gunner on one episode one exploitation move and I told him that if he could get permission from my crew that I'd be happy to have him.
So he got permission from the crew and this was his he he got in this tank and started
when we crossed the Rhine River.
So he had had five days and nights without any sleep, and now he had come on, and we were going all night again.
So he knocked out this tank of 1,500 meters.
It was kind of up on a hill.
He shot it into the track, and she started smoking, and the crew got out.
And then he got this one at 75 meters.
The next day at noon, we had bypassed the Tudor Burger Wall, got through it, and we're moving out, and he called me and he said, sir, I would like now to go back to be mess sergeant.
I said, not until this battle's over, you're doing too well.
What do you say to that?
Well, he stayed with me, of course.
But he was a very proud guy.
How many casualties did you take in this tank battle?
I never lost a tank.
Never lost a tank, never lost a man.
The only two guys that got really in serious trouble was a division commander.
We were engaging in this tank battle and stuff was coming back and forth, back and forth on this parallel road and a truck came down this road.
And I told the recon units, I said, now wait until this truck gets right down in front of us and then blow it away with .50 caliber.
And about that time, this guy punched me on the shoulder and he said, what's going on here?
And at that time, they shot this truck up 50 yards away out here on this road.
You can see it.
And it turned and swerved and the ground was wet and it was loaded with German wax.
And it's carried...
scattered dead and wounded women all over the road.
And this guy said, what's going on here?
I said, look, you old son of a bitch.
I said, don't you know that there's a battle going on here, and you get the hell out of here.
Who'd you say that to now?
The division commander, the two-star general.
Oh, okay.

And he told General Patton later after the war, he said, this is the greatest battalion commander in the war, he said, and he's also the only guy that ever called me a son of a bitch and got by with it.
As a division commander.
Would you believe that Did your division commander call you up or was he No, he'd come up on a jeep, come up through the area, traveling all night back there, coming up behind me.
To get up to you and find out what the heck was going on.
And he got up there and we were in this battle.
So he said, and General Patton said, well, what'd you do, I.D.
He said, I did just like he told me.
I got the hell out of there.
So... We went on down a little ways, and here they...
Here, I looked around, and I'm in my tank now.
We're fighting and moving.
And here is a guy behind me with...
in a Jeep.
And I looked around there.
About that time, Cooley killed his tank.
I saw this tank gun come out of this fir tree right over there.
And Cooley saw him at the same time, and without any order, they just blew him all to hell.
Hit around, hit under the edge of the turret, blew it out.
And I looked around.
And this brigadier was in the road ditch out of his jeep.
The driver was laying on the road and he was in the ditch.
So I jumped out of my tank.
I said, oh my God, somebody has killed our assistant division commander.
So I get out there.
I run where he is.
I said, what?
I said, General Hines?
His name was Sid Hines, H-I-N-D-S. And I said, General Hines, you all right?
He said, yes, but this is too close for an old man.
And he got in that Jeep, and whew, he took off.
Well, that was a good day.
Was his driver killed?
No, no one.
They were falling right behind my tank, protecting my tank.
And when my tank gun went off, you know, and the blast out of that muzzle brake comes off, boy, that is hair-raising.
They got in the ditch.
They didn't know what was happening.
And he took off.
But we...
We proceeded on.
And you didn't lose one tank.
Not one single tank.
Not one single soldier.
You didn't lose a soldier, and how many German tanks did you knock out?
Not very many.
Most of them were retreating and getting away from us.
I would say in a 56-mile day, a big day, we made 56 miles in the pursuit.
And we may have knocked out 10 or 11 vehicles of different types, that's all.
Most thin-skinned vehicles were rear guard trying to get away, leaving infantry behind.
And the infantry was firing bazookas at us from houses and all that sort of stuff.
Oh, were they?
Yeah, yeah.
So that must have been kind of dangerous.
Oh, it was very hairy.
This Sergeant Happy
was in an armored car and a guy from a tree at about 75 meters only less than 75 meters fired a Panzerfaust a rocket anything rocket called Panzerfaust now shaped charge and it hit the
ring of his M8 armored car, which it has a .50 caliber on, on the M8 armored car, four-wheel armored car, very likely, and he hit the ring, burned a hole, so he could kill Sergeant Happy.
Now, Sergeant Happy was in his eighth campaign.
He had landed in Africa with us.
That's a hell of a loss, you know.
A hell of a loss for anybody to lose any soldier, but a guy that's gone through that much, you know.
So we lost him.
We got involved with it.
So most of the resistance then by this time was light and scattered.
Light and scattered and mostly infantry with some light vehicles and equipment and most of it anti-tank gun, handheld rockets, anti-tank rockets.
Why weren't they surrendering?
They knew they were beat.
Well, they were trying to surrender but I have to give you an example of what happened.
I ran into, I stayed right with the reconnaissance element.
And we started drawing small arms fire.
And one guy stepped behind a tree and I pulled out a carbine rifle to shoot him.
It snapped and I threw it down in the road ditch.
I never did pick it up and I killed him with a pistol.
I could wear a pistol here and one down here.
If you're inside a tank, you can't get at this one.
So you've got to have something you can get at so you want a shoulder holster.
If you're down on the ground Why didn't he shoot you?
Huh?
Why didn't he shoot you?
Well, he did raise to shoot me, but I just happened to beat him to the draw.
No kidding?
Yeah.
How far away was he?
He was about 30 yards, 30, 40 yards.
He stepped out from behind a tree and raised his rifle, and this old carbine snapped, and I just grabbed this pistol and fired it.
And at this time you were in what, a jeep?
I was in a jeep.
And the other guy dropped his rifle and gave up.
Hayes, my radio operator in a jeep, Sergeant Hayes was a fluent speaker of German.
He had a lot of help.
John Rossell from Cleveland, he was a driver and a courageous guy.
So, Hayes got the word
They had a whole regiment out there and they wanted to give up.
But they couldn't give up because the SS in the next village was forcing them to fight.
See the SS threatening them and so, but they'd give up.
The whole regiment would give up.
They didn't want to fight.
So I told Hayes, I said, okay, Hayes, get the best location you can on this damn place where they are in this village from this guy.

He wasn't quite certain, but he knew that they were in about the center of town in a building that had a wooden fence around it, farm implements inside, animals inside, and they were staying inside the house, and they were up in the loft operating the radio.
I said, Hayes, give me a...
Let's stick one other man with us here.
You guys take more."
But I said, I think that they said ten or twelve of them in there.
I said, we'll slip around down there.
We'll get behind this village and we'll take these guys on.
Meantime, I told columns spread out.

get off the road, get themselves deployed, that I was going to see if I couldn't get this regiment to surrender, draw up the artillery, and here's where I'm going, and cover me, and I'd call for artillery if I needed, or whatever tank, whatever I needed.
So, this village was about a mile away.
So we went off down to Hearts Mountain, which is on my right flank.
I go off down there and I found a, we go across the field, we go down in the low land, we come along and we get on up, myself, one recon sergeant, Hayes, and Rochelle, we go on up.
We go back about a mile behind this place and we come in behind it.
And just outside town we find a guy with a horse and a small wagon filled with loaves of bread.
A German?
German.
So we snatch him and we make him tell us where this place is.
As a matter of fact,
We go up within one block of where this is and make him point this out.
Then Rochelle, Hayes, and Sergeant Sullivan, I believe it was, a recon sergeant.
I'm armed with a Tommy gun, and I still wear my two pistols.
Others are armed.
Hayes has a Tommy gun, and Sergeant has an M1 and a pistol.
and we all got grenades.
So we go up there and this German pointed out You go into the city then?
Oh yeah, it's a small village.
One road goes through it and houses off to the right and left.
Farming area.
All the farmers live in here, you see, and they farm the lands out there.
And there's a whole regiment of Germans in there?
Only twelve SS guys.
Twelve SS are here in the village.
And my troops are out there and the German regiment's out here.
So I work my way all the way around here and I come back in the back way.
So we go in there.
Satisfied that that's the place.
How many of you snuck in there?
Four of us.
Why did you go if you're the commander?
I just got the information.
And I want to go.
You don't waste time waiting to put a team together and so on and so forth.
You deploy everybody, tell the force what you're going to do, and then you go do it.
Well, who was in charge?
Who'd you leave in charge of?
I left my deputy in charge, my executive in charge.
He's in the half track in the command center with my S-3 and my S-2 and my S-1.
So we go in there, we knock this wooden door down, and we start spraying this thing.
So we kill them all but four.
And these were all SS?
SS, all SS.
We put the Dark uniforms and all that?
Yeah, we put the four SS, they're not dead, with their hands behind their head, walking them in front of the jeep, out in the regiment, the whole regiment gives up white flags.
And these guys had given up.
Funny thing happened.
So the whole regiment?
The whole regiment.
There was only about 1,600, 1,700 of them, and all of them older people called Volkstrom's regiment, People's regiment.
So they were pretty much militia.
Oh, yeah, sure.
They were lucky to have that, I guess, at that point in time.
They were in their 40s and above.
Yeah, that's right.
And they were not eager to fight anyway.
Not eager to fight.

I didn't want to kill people like that so we did this very swiftly very quickly and believe it or not a funny story that I heard the next day was that we made them stack up their rifles you know and armored elements have no way of carrying prisoners and oftentimes we get accused of
The paratroopers and the armored people get accused of killing prisoners because they got no way to take care of them.
They're often accused of that, but that's not true.
What we do in armored elements is we tell them to stack their weapons up, put their hands behind their head, and start walking to the rear.
A soldier is a soldier, and there's honor among soldiers.

always exceptions of course but amongst these people they didn't want to fight in the first place so they're not gonna bother anybody we stack up their weapon lo and behold the adjunct of the regiment was coming forward in his Jeep with his driver to bring mail or something
And he's a nice, timid little man, officer.
That's the reason he's the adjutant, you know, of the regiment.
And lo and behold, he looks here, and here are all these Germans coming down the damn road.
So he gets his .45 out and recaptures them.
And it's getting dark, and he does not know what to do, and his radio and his jeep isn't working, and he's scared to death.
So the story goes is that he got in the middle and made the Germans march around him all night long.
Somebody come along at first light and helped him out.
He had captured a whole regiment single-handed.
I thought that was funny when I heard that.
What did the general say?
What did White say?
Oh, God, they laughed about that for weeks.
Still laughing about it, I guess.
Were you and your other three men recommended for a decoration?
I think the division commander gave us silver stars.
It was pretty bloody in there for a while.
They were shooting them.
We were shooting them.
Did you lose any of your men?
No, not a scratch.
Really?
Not a scratch.
You just, all four of you?
Blasted, blasted.
Throwing the grenades in the house, throwing the grenades here and blasting.
You pick these guys up, the ones on the radio up here, we just cut them out and they rolled out of that hayloft down on the ground.
One come out of the basement there that had been wounded and Hayes told him to get his hands up.
He tried to spit on Hayes, and that's when I pulled his pistol and cut him from right here, right all the way down through here.
Because nobody spits on my sergeant.
Not even America.
So I cut him across the head here with my .45, and then he got his hands up.
But those SS are awful surly, disciplined, tough cookies.
Tough cookies, and black suitors.
tough cookie.
But that regiment got up and moved out.
What did you feel like when you were going into this barn?
Well, I felt like you're gonna win or you don't go.
You felt like you're gonna be successful or you just don't tackle anything like that.
And you had so much
experienced by this time in your seventh or eighth campaign in three years that you get a little bit careless, but if you get too careless, you're going to end up dead.
But also, you've got to remember that you've been through a lot, you've learned a lot, and if you apply it properly, you're a pretty tough cookie yourself, you know.
And you're not afraid to take anybody on.
really and it does so much for your soldier you know if the officer never asked a soldier to do anything that he hasn't done or won't do himself that's you gain their respect and confidence

and I'm telling you when you gain the respect and the confidence of an American soldier and he's trained you're going to see it he's trained you gain his respect and confidence uh there's no end to what you can't do I mean you can take on the greatest odds you've ever seen there isn't any question about that in my mind because
This guy called American, he makes the finest fighting man there is.
He may not behe's a poor fighter if he isn't led well.
He's a poor fighter if he isn't led well.
But if he's led well, there's no end to what he can't do.
And won't do.
And once you jumped into this place and started shooting, these guys, which were obviously outmanned, they didn't have any machine guns, they started shooting back?
They had very sub-machine guns.
Most all of them had sub-machine guns.
Pistols they wore.
But there was no time for pistols when you were faced with Tommy guns, .45 caliber Tommy guns.
with 20 and 30 round clips.

We got rid of the old drum, 50 caliber drum, because we had so many stoppages and so hard to carry and but with the 20 and 30 round clips or magazines you could stick them in your pockets, you could tie them, you could put tape on them hand to hand with 20 rounds here and turn the thing over another you got 40 rounds right there hanging on the gun.
And it's a good round for close range, a .45 caliber is a good round for close range.
I can't believe that this one guy actually spit after it was all over.
Well, he wouldn't have come out of the building there, you know.
What the hell was going on?
Did you actually go into the building or did you stay out and shoot in?
We just threw grenades inside the house, opened the door and dropped grenades, rolled them down the basement down there.
And didn't have to go in.
They started coming out of there.
Found out that they were all out.
And so this guy actually Oh yeah, he spit at Hayes and that's when he got cut.
Got his head busted open with a lot of pistols.
I had Captain Einbeck, his family came from Einbeck, Germany, and when we took that place, when I took that place, he wanted to go back and look for his aunt or uncle.
Now that was against the rules for us to allow our soldiers to go look for their ancestry over there.
You had some pretty close ancestry.
And damn good ancestry.
I finally told Einbeck he could go.
I said, yeah, go back to the town of Einbeck.
His aunt and uncle lived there, and his mother's sister.
He went back.
He finally found them.
but he was sorry about going back and looking for them because they give him the same sort of treatment.
He had to just turn and walk away.
They were not all that way, but some were.
But we Wait, how'd you get along with just the German refugees themselves?
You must have just streamed past them.
Oh, we got along with them.
I tell you what, they were a troublesome lot, particularly a displaced person.
Yeah.
Displaced persons were a worrisome lot.
First off, they were all hungry and when you give them rations most of them become very ill with diarrhea because they hadn't had anything to eat and then when
And you had to keep guards on them because if you didn't, they'd go out and ransack every German village, kill every cow, kill every horse.
They were just mad people.
Just mad people.
So you had to keep them under control and then the reaction you got, well here you come you great liberators and now you're treating us just like the Germans did.
You see?
So it's a sort of problem that

I guess there are many approaches to how you handle dispersed people that's been in prison for a long time and mistreated and no food and they're kind of wild because they're very destructive if they're left alone as a group and you can't help that happen.
So it's a difficult
thing to figure out just how to handle it.
And they were interested in revenge against the Germans?
Absolutely, totally, totally.
And were there incidences that you had to stop?
Oh yeah, they got stealing cows, ramsacking the places.
They were, I believe the displaced people were as bad as the Soviets.
Soviets, they ramsacked every house and every cellar
took every jar of food that the Germans had been able to muster together.
And the Germans are much like Americans, and Americans are much like the Germans.
And we're one and the same in many respects.
They're great preservers of food during the food seasons, if they can get their hands on it, fresh vegetables and that sort of stuff, by canning it and storing it and putting it away.
jellies and jams and that sort of type of staple, but Soviet soldiers were just ramsacking their house stealing everything that they could get, eating out of these jars and cans.
They were, it seemed to me that they were almost as starved to death as the DPs were.
Well, we're going to get to the Soviets in a minute, but now that we're talking about
refugees and we always have that problem of looting.
Did you have any examples with your men or did you hear of any examples in which Americans were looting?
I don't think so.
Maybe they did.
It's a hard thing to say in war what is left at the end of a day's battle and what it's cost one side or the other.
And what one side feels like it deserves as a result of victory or what one feels like it deserves as a result of the loss of battle.
And I guess I'm trying to avoid your question because I never saw a soldier loot anything.
Now, maybe they did, but I didn't see that.
I wasn't looking for that.
I was looking to see that we won the battle and that I saved as many soldiers' lives as I could and I was doing the kind of job that I was capable of doing.
I've heard that soldiers looted.
Maybe they did.
Maybe they picked up something and found out later that what am I doing with this thing and throw it away.
How much loot can you put on a soldier that has 96 pounds of
pack and weapon and ammunition on him.
How much loot can he carry?
I'm just asking.
There's another thing that we should talk about since you were right there on the front lines.
The Russians even admitted that the amount of looting that the Red Army did was horrible, and also of course the hatred between
the Russians and the Germans was much more intense than between the Germans and the Americans, but there was quite a bit of raping that was going on.
What about that?
Did you have any situations?
No, we had a policy of non-fraternization, and I think everybody stuck to that as far as I could tell.
I never had a rape problem.
Anything like that going on out in the battle area, I don't know where the women were.
There's some old women out there, and some old men left, and I don't know where in the hell the younger people were, but I don't think any soldier is interested in raping some 70-year-old farm woman.
I just didn't have any of it.
I told them, well, the rules were you just don't do that sort of stuff.
and they didn't do it.
If they had, I'd have dealt with them very harshly because they knew there was no in-between with me.
After this surrender, then what?
Let's continue until the end, until V.E.
Day.
After the surrender, we moved from Was this in February or March?
No, April.
We're talking about April 45.
because I was wounded on the Elbe River on the 11th of April.
A part of the regiment of Germans came down from the north and wanted to surrender to me.
The lieutenant colonel brought his force in, and he came down under the white flag and wanted to join me to go to Berlin.
And I said, I've just been more or less reprimanded for even attempting to cross the Elbe River.
I didn't know any better, and I fought all night to try to take this bridge, and I've been busted up.
I was busted up, but nobody ever told me that this was going to be the international boundary, so I was trying to save the bridge.
Anyway, this German regiment of about 900 people came down and wanted to join me to go to Berlin, and I wish to hell that

I had authority to go because I took Burrell in about eleven hours and there wouldn't have been any killing or anything going on up there and it would have been a different world totally different world than the one today but in my personal view Mr. Eisenhower and a very sick president Mr. Roosevelt were bamboozled
by Stalin and the old American position of, let's get this war over with and bring our boys home.
And Mr. Bradley, General Bradley saying, oh, it'll cost us 100,000 casualties to take Berlin.
Well, that was a bunch of crap.
I think I could have took Berlin in 11 hours from the 11th of April with those 900 Germans or without them.
In about 11 hours, I would have been to Berlin, and I don't think there had been any problem of the whole Berlin giving up at that time without any casualties whatsoever.
That was the attitude of the German people, and that was the attitude of the German army at the time because, as I say there,
They wanted to go with me to Berlin, and they thought that there's nothing but sense to this business that the United States go to Berlin, and they were right.
But no, the decision had been made long before that that we're going to give that to the Soviets.
What a hell of a disaster for the American people.
and you can blame Eisenhower and Roosevelt for it.
What did this German lieutenant colonel say to you?
He said, I want to join you and go to Berlin with you.
He wanted to fight with you?
He wanted to join us and go with us.
They knew what the hell was going to happen.
And liberate it?
Yeah.
Take it before the Soviets get there.
That's what he told you?
Oh, yeah.
They all knew this.
Most of these guys, a high percentage of them had been on the Eastern Front.
They know the Soviets.
They know communism.
I just told him, I said,
I'm not permitted to cross the Elk River and we just had casualties trying to get across the Elk River.
A regimental commander, Colonel Paul Disney, took a piece of shell fragment in the leg.
But nobody told us that that was an international boundary, we're not supposed to cross it.
I said to the German, I said, you put your stuff out here.
And he said, well, what'll I do with my troops?
I said, line them up out there someplace.
He said, how about their weapons?
I said, you save enough weapons to safeguard those men and stack the rest of them up out in front of your unit there.
I said, how much have you had to eat today?
He said, our ration today is two small potatoes.
I said, well, what you want to do is get your men lined up out here and I'm going to send for a truckload of food some rations for you.
And I did.
I called a little guy named Sam Smith who was my supply officer and I said, get a truckload of rations up here for these German prisoners.
Well, yes, sir, where are they?
I said, well, it doesn't make a damn where they are.
I said, get the hell on up here, and I'll point out to you where they are.
So they got them up there.
We give them the whole two-and-a-half-ton truckload of rations.
Of course, they starved to death.
God mighty.
Next day, they were all sick because the food was too rich for them, the C-rations.

You know, those sea rations got a variety of different kinds of food there, but they did have some coffee and some cigarettes and some things like that, and they hadn't had coffee and cigarettes in God knows when.
So they were all sick to their stomach?
Diarrhea?
Oh yeah, all over the place.
Just too much for them.
They were all too thin?
They were all real thin?
Yeah, they were.
Well, you know,

they're strong they're not I don't know how to describe a man that gets around to the point that he doesn't eat very much in his system and justice to it but they weren't weaklings you know that's what I guess I'm trying to say they're still damn physical capable of fighting like hell but uh
That gives you some idea about what I felt about our prisoners.
I tried to take care of them.
And that's where you were when V.E.
Day came about.
Yeah, that's right.
You were sitting on the Elbe.
That's right, that's right.
Waiting for orders.
Waiting for orders.
Orders were withdraw to Brunswick, so we withdrew to Brunswick.
And war was over, and the Poles were running all over the damn place.
Oh, they busted down their damn cages and, you know, the POW, their Displaced Person Cages.
God, oh my, they were a mess.
And we immediately started moving into occupation, military government.
Rounded them up and got Polish, appointed Polish captains.
of labor forces give one Pole responsible for looking after and maintaining order among the Poles.
Let the Poles argue this thing out themselves, you know.
And they seemed to get a hold of themselves.
How did they respond to Americans?
Were they happy to see you?
Oh, yes.
All of the prisoner camps that were uncovered, which I didn't uncover
P.O.W., our own P.O.W.
camp.
We did uncover the D.P.
camps.
They were very, very happy.
And of course, we gave them food.
Sure, and they got sick.
Yeah, just couldn't handle it.
funny thing about that stuff.
But, I had a terrible fight on the Elk River when I got there.
I guess Cornelius Ryan tells it better than I, because he got his information from everybody.
But, I was over living
overlooking Schoenbeck about five o'clock in the evening on the Elbe River and there was a bridge there.
And the Germans were moving in a column from south to north and going in the town and it's obvious to me they were trying to get across the Elbe River to get out of the way.
Tanks, artillery pieces, horse drawn artillery,
truck-drawn artillery, personnel carriers filled with people, armored personnel carriers, headquarters vehicles and all that, bumper-to-bumper movement.
So I called Jim Starr, one of my company commanders, and I said, I'm going to put a company of infantry on your back, and I want you to go just at dark and chop that column off.
I'm going to take the other two companies.
How was he going to get across the Elm?
They were on this side.
Oh, they were on this side.
Yeah, going parallel to the Elm.
Oh, I see.
Yeah, from north to south, from south to north.
And they were going into Schoenbeck, and I knew damn well they were crossing that bridge.
That bridge was still open.
So I said, Jim, I want you to go
We were on high ground in defilade position watching all that.
And I said, I want you to go charging down there about a mile and a half down there with the high ground up here overlooking all that.
I said, I want you to go down there and chop that column in two and stop it and tear her up or capture her, however you can do it.
I'm going to go charging in town
